139.author: Robert Hahn
139.bottom_line: We maintain uncertainty surrounding interfaces 3 ft down in the snowpack that could produce a very large avalanche. Any slabs avalanche you trigger in the new snow, cornice, or even a human could all trigger this low-likelihood, high consequence problem.  Choose slopes less than 35 degrees if you venture onto larger terrain features.
139.hazard_discussion:
NWAC and NPS professionals reported 35 inches of "right-side-up" or increasing density snow above the decomposing 1/13 rain crust.  Near-surface facets above the 1/13 crust and surface hoar several inches above that are showing signs of rounding. These layers are becoming a low likelihood, high consequence threat. The observers noted an impressive avalanche cycle from the January 31 - Feb 2 storm cycle.  Crowns were particularly prevalent on NE aspects where almost every steep, convex rollover produced an avalanche. Some aspects could still be close to the tipping point, but just waiting for a trigger. This uncertainty warrants increased caution and a greater margin for safety on Friday.

2020-21 Forecast Schedule: Avalanche danger ratings will be issued for the Olympics every Friday through Sunday and during mid-week holidays. During the week when the Hurricane Ridge road is closed, forecast information will be updated daily to include expected conditions and relevant travel advice under the No Rating label.

During the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic, continue to follow the latest guidance from local, state, and federal health officials. Avoid unnecessary risks that could impact first responders and stress medical resources.  Wear a mask when appropriate, practice social distancing, and consider recreating closer to home.

media.caption: (2/4/2021) 1/13 crust with rounding surface hoar layer above.
(2/4/2021) Persistent Slab crown profile.
(1/30/2021) Human triggered persistent slab avalanche stepping down to 1/13 crust.  Estimated to be size D1.5. North facing aspect near Victoria Overlook. Photo:  Ashley Turcotte - NPS

forecast_avalanche_problems.discussion: You are likely to trigger a small wind slab near ridgelines and in above treeline terrain. Focus on the snow that drifts on the slopes since the end of the day on Thursday where you might find a shallow temperature crust up to 5000 ft or so. Several inches of fresh snow with moderate to occasionally strong westerly winds will load lee slopes. While the wind forecast has been for consistent W winds, winds on Hurricane Ridge have been and may continue to come from a variety of directions. Check the direction of fresh sharp cornices and wind lips, rime plastered on trees, and snow stripped from trees. Steer around recently wind-loaded terrain features near treeline and avoid all slopes steeper than 35 degrees above treeline.

media.caption: Example of wind-affected snow below corniced ridgelines where you are more likely to trigger a wind slab avalanche. Photo: Ethan Taylor

forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Wind Slab
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Wind Slab avalanches are the release of a cohesive layer of snow (a slab) formed by the wind. Wind typically transports snow from the upwind sides of terrain features and deposits snow on the downwind side. Wind slabs are often smooth and rounded and sometimes sound hollow, and can range from soft to hard. Wind slabs that form over a persistent weak layer (surface hoar, depth hoar, or near-surface facets) may be termed Persistent Slabs or may develop into Persistent Slabs.

forecast_avalanche_problems.discussion: Persistent slab avalanches are still on our minds and they should be on yours. The primary layer of concern involves facets above a crust about 35 inches below the surface. About 2-3 inches above that interface, there is a layer of surface hoar. Persistent slabs are notoriously slow to heal, propagate widely, and these are still within the range of human trigger. They can also be triggered by cornice collapse or a wind slab avalanche.  Any avalanche on either weak layer will be large to very large and difficult to survive. Although snowpack test results were not impressive, similar layers of rounding facets and surface hoar in the Cascades have produced numerous avalanches, some of them human-triggered. Given our uncertainty surrounding this layer, we suggest continuing to dial back your terrain selection. Reduce your exposure to avalanche terrain steeper than 35 degrees.

media.caption: (2/4/2021) Persistent slab avalanche that likely failed naturally during the storm (around 2/1). Hurricane Ridge Road in the foreground. Photo: Sam Luthy.

forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Persistent Slab
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Persistent Slab avalanches are the release of a cohesive layer of snow (a slab) in the middle to upper snowpack, when the bond to an underlying persistent weak layer breaks. Persistent layers include: surface hoar, depth hoar, near-surface facets, or faceted snow. Persistent weak layers can continue to produce avalanches for days, weeks or even months, making them especially dangerous and tricky. As additional snow and wind events build a thicker slab on top of the persistent weak layer, this avalanche problem may develop into a Deep Persistent Slab.

140.author: Matt Primomo
140.bottom_line: Very dangerous avalanche conditions are expected near and above treeline, so avoid traveling into places where avalanches can start, run, and stop. You could trigger large and surprising avalanches in steep, open terrain where weak snow sits over a slick crust. Professionals have observed clean and planer failures in the upper snowpack, and we expect conditions to become active on these deeper layers on Friday.
140.hazard_discussion:
We are headed into another storm cycle, and this time Stevens Pass could do fairly well with new snow amounts. We don't expect the snowpack to be able to handle this storm very well, because professionals have observed sudden, planer, and often easy failures with snowpit tests in the upper pack. Others have observer spooky collapsing. Weak snow above and sometimes within the crust from January 13th is now a concern in the zone with added snow and wind loading. Until recently, there hasn't been much new snow or slab over this layer, but we expect that to change on Friday. 

Under the thicker canopy of the trees, the snow conditions may begin to improve with this storm. Previously they were variable, with icy, bumpy surfaces and plenty of downed trees and branches. 

During the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic, continue to follow the latest guidance from local, state, and federal health officials. Avoid unnecessary risks that could impact first responders and stress medical resources.  Wear a mask when appropriate, practice social distancing, and consider recreating closer to home.

media.caption: (2/3/2021) This crack came from a whumph we heard while stepping on a thick wind pillow. It fractured on the slick 1/13 crust, about 1.5ft deep.
(2/3/2021) Clean, easy tilt test results below a recent crust. South aspect at 5,000ft on Lichtenberg.
(2/3/2021) Small rounded facets on a 2 and 3mm grid, found down 15" on south aspect at 5,000ft on Lichtenberg. Test results indicated sudden, clean failures, and the ability for propagation.

(2/3/2021) A person touring along the ridgeline from Artist Point to Huntoon Point remotely triggered a cornice that fell onto the slope below triggering this large avalanche.  The avalanche occurred on a NE aspect at 5000ft and failed about 1 meter deep on the 1/24 interface.

I travelled to the Lanham Lake area on Sunday. This pit profile photo is representative of many hasty pits that I dug in the area. The uppermost crust from Jan 24 had a thin layer of facets above it in some areas. Where those facets were present failures occurred easily on that layer.
Long shooting cracks are indicators of unstable snow surfaces, which may avalanche if the slope is steep enough.
Skier triggered wind slab avalanches are possible at higher elevations on Wednesday.

forecast_avalanche_problems.discussion: Significant new snowfall is expected with fluctuating temperatures and very strong wind. It doesn't take a rocket scientist to tell us that conditions will be prime for avalanches on Friday. Stay aware as you travel through snow and take notice if you see shooting cracks or recent soft avalanches. The new snow will sit over a variety of weak surfaces and older weak layers. In some areas you could produce deeper and more surprising avalanches. Strong wind will also redistribute snow in exposed terrain. For these reasons, avoid slopes that are steeper than 30 degrees.

media.caption: Example storm slab on a small test slope.

forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Storm Slab
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Storm Slab avalanches are the release of a cohesive layer (a slab) of new snow that breaks within new snow or on the old snow surface. Storm-slabs typically last between a few hours and few days (following snowfall). Storm-slabs that form over a persistent weak layer (surface hoar, depth hoar, or near-surface facets) may be termed Persistent Slabs or may develop into Persistent Slabs.

forecast_avalanche_problems.discussion: The new snow will stress deeper weak layers in the snowpack, and you could trigger wide and surprising avalanches. These could be 2ft+ deep and could be triggered from a distance or from below on connected slopes. Look for shooting cracks and whumphing collapses as telltale signs of instability. The problem appears to be variable throughout the mountains. Some slopes may have the ability to create these large and surprising avalanches, while other ones may not. The tricky part is that it will be very difficult to tell. When the snowpack is this complex, keep your terrain choices simple. Elevations below 4,500ft may offer significantly lower chances of triggering one of these.

media.caption: (2/5/2021) This avalanche was remotely triggered in backcountry terrain just outside of the Crystal ski area. Similar to other recent slides, it failed on facets just above the 1/13 crust. 60cm deep, 150' wide. 5200' ESE aspect. Photo: Crystal Mt Ski Patrol

forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Persistent Slab
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Persistent Slab avalanches are the release of a cohesive layer of snow (a slab) in the middle to upper snowpack, when the bond to an underlying persistent weak layer breaks. Persistent layers include: surface hoar, depth hoar, near-surface facets, or faceted snow. Persistent weak layers can continue to produce avalanches for days, weeks or even months, making them especially dangerous and tricky. As additional snow and wind events build a thicker slab on top of the persistent weak layer, this avalanche problem may develop into a Deep Persistent Slab.

141.author: Dallas Glass
141.bottom_line: Recent avalanches, weak snowpack structure, heavy precipitation, mild temperatures, and strong winds all point towards one thing; very dangerous avalanche conditions. Stay away from anywhere an avalanche can start, run, or stop.
141.hazard_discussion:
The current weather and snowpack setup check all the boxes for a natural avalanche cycle. While the heaviest precipitation may occur before dawn, loading should continue into the day along with natural avalanches. A weak snowpack structure has been well documented through numerous observations across the zone. We expect this storm to tip the scales and cause avalanches on these buried older weak layers. 

Currently, two layers of concern exist in the upper snowpack. 1). A thin crust (2/1) with weak snow above and below. In some cases, facets and/or surface hoar were observed at this interface. Natural and triggered avalanches occurred on this layer Thursday. As it gets buried deeper it could become more reactive and produce large avalanches. 2). The 1/13 crust and facets now lay deep in the snowpack (3’ or more by Friday morning). So far, we have not seen significant avalanche activity on this layer. However, it has been very active in adjacent forecast zones. You could trigger avalanches on this layer or shallower slides might step-down and fail on these weak old snow grains. 

Snow pits and snowpack tests serve as great tools for tracking these persistent layers but don’t overlook the critical “red-flag” data. Recent natural and triggered avalanches, persistent grains, in the snowpack, significant loading, strong winds, and relatively warm temperatures all indicate unstable snow.

During the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic, continue to follow the latest guidance from local, state, and federal health officials. Avoid unnecessary risks that could impact first responders and stress medical resources.  Wear a mask when appropriate, practice social distancing, and consider recreating closer to home.

media.caption: (2/4/2021) This thin slab failed just above the 2/1 crust in the Alpental Valley on Thursday (02/04). It was one of many small avalanches observed in the area. Photo Joe Hoch

(2/3/2021) This snow profiles shows a similar snowpack structure to other areas in the zone. The 1/13 crust sits about 25-30cm below the surface. The 2/1 crust failed in several tests with small facets underneath. However, at the moment, it' very shallow.
(2/3/2021) These 1mm facets were sampled from just above the 1/13 crust. While they show signs of rounding, they remain very weak and failed in several snowpack tests. NE 4800', Keechelus Ridge.
(1/31/2021) Pit from the Kendall slide paths on Sunday 1/31

forecast_avalanche_problems.discussion: This storm on its own would likely produce significant avalanche activity. As it combines with a weak snowpack structure you could see surprising slides that trigger remotely, step-down into older snow layers, and run far distances. On Thursday, three separate groups of professionals reported avalanches failing just above the 2/1 crust. These thin slabs propagated widely across features. By Friday morning this same weak layer will be 18-24” deep and much more concerning. Stay away from all avalanche terrain including areas where avalanches run and stop.

media.caption: (2/4/2021) This thin avalanche failed just above the 2/1 crust layer in the Snow Lake Divide area of Snoqualmie Pass. Similar natural and human triggered slides were reported by several professionals at Snoqualmie Pass. Photo Renne Shapiro.

forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Persistent Slab
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Persistent Slab avalanches are the release of a cohesive layer of snow (a slab) in the middle to upper snowpack, when the bond to an underlying persistent weak layer breaks. Persistent layers include: surface hoar, depth hoar, near-surface facets, or faceted snow. Persistent weak layers can continue to produce avalanches for days, weeks or even months, making them especially dangerous and tricky. As additional snow and wind events build a thicker slab on top of the persistent weak layer, this avalanche problem may develop into a Deep Persistent Slab.

forecast_avalanche_problems.discussion: The forecast shows the rain-snow line should stay just above pass level more much of the day. As a result, expect a wet and punchy snow surface that could produce natural loose avalanches. Closer to the rain-snow line these slides may entrain significant snow and grow large. Stay off of and out from under very steep slopes, especially during periods of heavy precipitation.

media.caption: (12/18/2020) Example: This loose wet avalanche was triggered by a tree bomb on the Alpental Rd.

forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Wet Loose
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Wet Loose avalanches are the release of wet unconsolidated snow or slush. These avalanches typically occur within layers of wet snow near the surface of the snowpack, but they may quickly gouge into lower snowpack layers. Like Loose Dry Avalanches, they start at a point and entrain snow as they move downhill, forming a fan-shaped avalanche. Other names for loose-wet avalanches include point-release avalanches or sluffs. Loose Wet avalanches can trigger slab avalanches that break into deeper snow layers.

142.author: Andrew Kiefer
142.bottom_line: New snow and wind will cause natural avalanches at upper elevations over the next 24 hours. Weak layers deep in the snowpack could act in surprising ways and produce destructive and unsurvivable avalanches. Avoid open slopes 30 degrees and steeper and stay far away from avalanche path runout zones.
142.hazard_discussion:
Observations continue to trickle in documenting the impressive recent avalanche cycle throughout the West North zone. Avalanches were reported each of the past 11 days, with a heavy loading event (4ft snow, 8.5in water) and several rounds of natural activity January 30- February 2. Many long time locals and professionals reported avalanches in areas they had never seen run, and avalanche paths produce slides larger than they can remember. Several close calls were also reported recently, including natural avalanches running on Mt. Herman's east face hitting Bagley Creek - a high traffic route just a few hundred yards away from the Heather Meadows parking area.

These are unusual and very dangerous conditions. Avalanches related to new snow and wind are concerning enough, and a lingering deep slab instability poses uncertainty and high consequences. Avoid avalanche terrain and be patient while the snowpack takes time to adjust and stabilize. 

During the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic, continue to follow the latest guidance from local, state, and federal health officials. Avoid unnecessary risks that could impact first responders and stress medical resources.  Wear a mask when appropriate, practice social distancing, and consider recreating closer to home.

media.caption: (1/2/2021) Observers on Monday captured video of two large natural avalanches on the east aspect of Mt. Herman. Both avalanches crossed high traffic routes along Bagley Creek, just a few hundred yards away from the Heather Meadows parking area.

(2/3/2021) A snowmobile triggered avalanche (D2) in the Excelsior area of Canyon Creek Wednesday. The avalanche occurred on a NW aspect at 5400ft and failed 1m (3ft) deep on the 1/24 interface which presented as a 10cm thick layer of faceted snow above the AR crust in this location.

(2/3/2021) A person touring along the ridgeline from Artist Point to Huntoon Point remotely triggered a cornice that fell onto the slope below triggering this large avalanche.  The avalanche occurred on a NE aspect at 5000ft and failed about 3ft deep on the 1/24 interface.
(2/4/2021) The crown of a recent natural avalanche (D3) on the south aspect of Mt. Herman near 5600ft. Photo: Simon Trautman
Very large avalanches propagated long distances during the storm. Photo: Mt Baker Ski Patrol

(2/3/2021) Crowns of large natural avalanches on Video Peak/Happy Bunny Butte on northerly aspects between 5200-5400ft. The avalanches occurred during the 01/30-02/02 storm and appear to have failed on the 1/24 interface.
(2/3/2021) Several natural avalanches (D2-D3) on the S and W aspects of Bacon Peak. The avalanches ran 01/30-02/02

forecast_avalanche_problems.discussion:
Heavy snowfall and strong westerly winds will build fresh slabs over the next 24 hours. Expect the bulk of precipitation to arrive overnight Thursday with the most dangerous avalanche conditions early morning Friday. Large natural avalanches are very likely near and above treeline on wind loaded slopes 35 degrees and steeper. Expect touchy conditions as new and windblown snow may not bond well to cold, low-density snow from earlier in the week.

If you venture out Friday, choose simple, low-angle terrain. Avalanches due to new snow and wind could step down and trigger deep weak layers in the snowpack resulting in very large avalanches. Avoid freshly wind-loaded features and anticipate variable loading patterns. Cornices will continue to grow and could drop onto slopes below acting as huge triggers.

media.caption: (1/29/2021) Example of a skier triggered avalanche in wind drifted snow. Photo: Pete Durr

forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Wind Slab
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Wind Slab avalanches are the release of a cohesive layer of snow (a slab) formed by the wind. Wind typically transports snow from the upwind sides of terrain features and deposits snow on the downwind side. Wind slabs are often smooth and rounded and sometimes sound hollow, and can range from soft to hard. Wind slabs that form over a persistent weak layer (surface hoar, depth hoar, or near-surface facets) may be termed Persistent Slabs or may develop into Persistent Slabs.

forecast_avalanche_problems.discussion:
A widespread natural avalanche cycle occurred during the storm January 30 - February 2. Numerous avalanches broke 3-4ft+ deep on a layer of weak faceted snow above a firm crust (January 24 interface). Avalanches grew very large (D3), had wide propagation wrapping large terrain features, and ran far distances hitting valley bottoms. A handful of avalanches were human triggered on this layer Wednesday, both in the Excelsior area of Canyon Creek (see photos below) and remotely triggered near Artist Point. Additional loading from new snow and wind will test this layer again and may produce another round of destructive avalanches.

The potential for natural and triggered deep persistent slab avalanches exists above 4000-4500ft on slopes 30 degrees and steeper. This is not a problem to try to outsmart. These conditions are difficult to manage and tricky to accurately assess. You can use snow profiles and snowpack tests to track these layers, but not necessarily as decision-making tools. Build in a wide margin for error and stay away from steep open slopes.

media.caption: (2/3/2021) Very large avalanches ran naturally on Mt Herman during the storm cycle between January 31 and February 2.

forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Deep Persistent Slab
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Deep Persistent Slab avalanches are the release of a thick cohesive layer of hard snow (a slab), when the bond breaks between the slab and an underlying persistent weak layer deep in the snowpack. The most common persistent weak layers involved in deep, persistent slabs are depth hoar or facets surrounding a deeply buried crust. Deep Persistent Slabs are typically hard to trigger, are very destructive and dangerous due to the large mass of snow involved, and can persist for months once developed. They are often triggered from areas where the snow is shallow and weak, and are particularly difficult to forecast for and manage.

143.author: Andrew Kiefer
143.bottom_line: New snow and wind will cause natural avalanches at upper elevations over the next 24 hours. Weak layers deep in the snowpack could act in surprising ways and produce destructive and unsurvivable avalanches. Avoid open slopes 30 degrees and steeper and stay far away from avalanche path runout zones.
143.hazard_discussion:
Observations continue to trickle in documenting the impressive recent avalanche cycle throughout the West North zone, along with large and surprising avalanches throughout the region. Avalanches were reported each of the past 11 days, with a heavy loading event (4ft snow, 8.5in water) and several rounds of natural activity January 30- February 2. Many long time locals and professionals reported avalanches in areas they had never seen run, and avalanche paths produce slides larger than they can remember. Several close calls were also reported recently, including natural avalanches running on Mt. Herman's east face hitting Bagley Creek - a high traffic route just a few hundred yards away from the Heather Meadows parking area.

These are unusual and very dangerous conditions. Avalanches related to new snow and wind are concerning enough, and a lingering deep slab instability poses uncertainty and high consequences. Avoid avalanche terrain and be patient while the snowpack takes time to adjust and stabilize. 

During the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic, continue to follow the latest guidance from local, state, and federal health officials. Avoid unnecessary risks that could impact first responders and stress medical resources.  Wear a mask when appropriate, practice social distancing, and consider recreating closer to home.

media.caption: (1/2/2021) Observers on Monday captured video of two large natural avalanches on the east aspect of Mt. Herman. Both avalanches crossed high traffic routes along Bagley Creek, just a few hundred yards away from the Heather Meadows parking area.

(2/3/2021) A snowmobile triggered avalanche (D2) in the Excelsior area of Canyon Creek Wednesday. The avalanche occurred on a NW aspect at 5400ft and failed 3ft deep on the 1/24 interface which presented as a 10cm thick layer of faceted snow above the AR crust in this location.

(2/3/2021) A person touring along the ridgeline from Artist Point to Huntoon Point remotely triggered a cornice that fell onto the slope below triggering this large avalanche.  The avalanche occurred on a NE aspect at 5000ft and failed about 3ft deep on the 1/24 interface.
(2/4/2021) The crown of a recent natural avalanche (D3) on the south aspect of Mt. Herman near 5600ft. Photo: Simon Trautman
Very large avalanches propagated long distances during the storm. Photo: Mt Baker Ski Patrol

(2/3/2021) Crowns of large natural avalanches on Video Peak/Happy Bunny Butte on northerly aspects between 5200-5400ft. The avalanches occurred during the 01/30-02/02 storm and appear to have failed on the 1/24 interface.
(2/3/2021) Several natural avalanches (D2-D3) on the S and W aspects of Bacon Peak. The avalanches ran 01/30-02/02

forecast_avalanche_problems.discussion:
Heavy snowfall and strong westerly winds will build fresh slabs over the next 24 hours. Expect the bulk of precipitation to arrive overnight Thursday with the most dangerous avalanche conditions early morning Friday. Large natural avalanches are very likely near and above treeline on wind loaded slopes 35 degrees and steeper. Expect touchy conditions as new and windblown snow may not bond well to cold, low-density snow from earlier in the week.

If you venture out Friday, choose simple, low-angle terrain. Avalanches due to new snow and wind could step down and trigger deep weak layers in the snowpack resulting in very large avalanches. Avoid freshly wind-loaded features and anticipate variable loading patterns. Cornices will continue to grow and could drop onto slopes below acting as huge triggers.

media.caption: (1/29/2021) Example of a skier triggered avalanche in wind drifted snow. Photo: Pete Durr

forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Wind Slab
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Wind Slab avalanches are the release of a cohesive layer of snow (a slab) formed by the wind. Wind typically transports snow from the upwind sides of terrain features and deposits snow on the downwind side. Wind slabs are often smooth and rounded and sometimes sound hollow, and can range from soft to hard. Wind slabs that form over a persistent weak layer (surface hoar, depth hoar, or near-surface facets) may be termed Persistent Slabs or may develop into Persistent Slabs.

forecast_avalanche_problems.discussion:
A widespread natural avalanche cycle occurred in the adjacent West North zone during the storm January 30 - February 2. Numerous avalanches broke 3-4ft+ deep on a layer of weak faceted snow above a firm crust (January 24 interface). Avalanches grew very large (D3), had wide propagation wrapping large terrain features, and ran far distances hitting valley bottoms. A handful of avalanches were human triggered on this layer Wednesday, both in the Excelsior area of Canyon Creek (see photos below) and remotely triggered near Artist Point. Additional loading from new snow and wind will test this layer again and may produce another round of destructive avalanches.

The potential for natural and triggered deep persistent slab avalanches exists above 4000-4500ft on slopes 30 degrees and steeper. This is not a problem to try to outsmart. These conditions are difficult to manage and tricky to accurately assess. You can use snow profiles and snowpack tests to track these layers, but not necessarily as decision-making tools. Build in a wide margin for error and stay away from steep open slopes.

media.caption: (2/3/2021) Very large avalanches ran naturally on Mt Herman during the storm cycle between January 31 and February 2.

forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Deep Persistent Slab
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Deep Persistent Slab avalanches are the release of a thick cohesive layer of hard snow (a slab), when the bond breaks between the slab and an underlying persistent weak layer deep in the snowpack. The most common persistent weak layers involved in deep, persistent slabs are depth hoar or facets surrounding a deeply buried crust. Deep Persistent Slabs are typically hard to trigger, are very destructive and dangerous due to the large mass of snow involved, and can persist for months once developed. They are often triggered from areas where the snow is shallow and weak, and are particularly difficult to forecast for and manage.

144.author: Dallas Glass
144.bottom_line: Clear “bulls-eye” data points to unstable snow, very dangerous avalanche conditions, and a natural avalanches cycle Friday. Stay away from anywhere an avalanche can start, run, or top.
144.hazard_discussion:
Recent avalanche activity, persistent weak layers, heavy precipitation, relatively mild temperatures, and strong winds check nearly all of the potential “red-flag” boxes for unstable snow. While the bulk of the storm arrives before dawn, significant precipitation should carry over into the day and with it the threat for natural avalanches. A well-documented weak snowpack structure exists across the entire West-South zone. The primary layer of concern remains a layer of sugary facets just above the prominent and thick 1/13 crust. As of Thursday afternoon, this layer sat 2-3’ deep in the snowpack. It will only be deeper Friday morning. The vast majority of avalanches and unstable snow observations came from the Crystal area with slightly lesser numbers from Mt St Helens and White Pass. So far, no avalanches have been reported on this layer near Paradise. Regardless, a similar snowpack structure exists in all locations, and we could see avalanche cycles peak at different times in different parts of the zone. 

A second layer of concern exists in the upper snowpack. A thin crust (2/1) with weak facets potentially above and/or below has been observed in a few locations. So far, this layer did not hold a significant slab above it. As this storm piles up snow, that should change. 

You can use snow profiles and snowpack tests to monitor these persistent weak layers, but don’t employ them as decision-making tools. The clear “bulls-eye” data should speak much louder than any one hole in the snow. If you dig, help us track the weak layers by submitting an observation.

During the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic, continue to follow the latest guidance from local, state, and federal health officials. Avoid unnecessary risks that could impact first responders and stress medical resources.  Wear a mask when appropriate, practice social distancing, and consider recreating closer to home.

media.caption: (2/3/2021) This natural avalanche likely occurred overnight on 02/02 in non-skier compacted terrain within Crystal Mt Ski Area. It failed on 1-2mm facets just above the 1/13 crust. 6300' NNE aspect. 85-95cm deep. Photo: Cyrstal Mt Ski Patrol
(2/1/2021) This small wind slab avalanche stepped down to the 1/23 facets above the thick prominent crust. Gunsight Bowl: N aspect, 6300',  18" crown. HS-ASc-D1.5-R2-O
(2/1/2021) This snow profile from Miriam creek near White Pass shows the facet layer of concern.
(2/1/2021) Recent winds loaded slopes in some unusual location, often opposite of where you might normally see wind slabs.

(1/29/2021) Multiple slabs were remotely triggered from a far distance by a snowmobiler on Mt. Saint Helens on Friday (1/29). There were multiple other slides remotely triggered and observed on the same day. [Photo: Kurt Heine]

(2/3/2021) This natural avalanche likely occurred overnight on 02/02. Similar to other slides it failed on facets above the 13 crust in non-skier compacted terrain of Crystal Mt. It occurred on a SE aspect at 6500'. Crown depth 2'. Photo: Crystal Mountain Ski Patrol

forecast_avalanche_problems.discussion: Natural and/or human triggered avalanches occurred every day for the past 9 days in the West South zone. Yet another remotely triggered slide took place outside of the skier area boundary at Crystal Mt on Thursday (5200’, ESE). We received reports of numerous avalanches near Crystal Mt, Mt St Helens, and White Pass over the past week. Some of these slides failed naturally, triggered remotely, stepped down into older layers, and caused other avalanches. Slides were documented in all elevation bands and on nearly every aspect. This persistent weak layer shows no signs of quieting down and may be just really waking-up. On Friday, significant new snow only makes this potentially dangerous snowpack structure scarier. This storm may tip the scales and produce a widespread avalanche cycle in some locations. Stay away from all avalanche terrain including where slide may run and stop.

media.caption: (2/5/2021) This avalanche was remotely triggered in backcountry terrain just outside of the Crystal ski area. Similar to other recent slides, it failed on facets just above the 1/13 crust. 60cm deep, 150' wide. 5200' ESE aspect. Photo: Crystal Mt Ski Patrol

forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Persistent Slab
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Persistent Slab avalanches are the release of a cohesive layer of snow (a slab) in the middle to upper snowpack, when the bond to an underlying persistent weak layer breaks. Persistent layers include: surface hoar, depth hoar, near-surface facets, or faceted snow. Persistent weak layers can continue to produce avalanches for days, weeks or even months, making them especially dangerous and tricky. As additional snow and wind events build a thicker slab on top of the persistent weak layer, this avalanche problem may develop into a Deep Persistent Slab.

forecast_avalanche_problems.discussion: Even without the threat of the persistent weak layer lurking in the snowpack, this winter storm should produce significant avalanche activity. Heavy snowfall, mild temperatures, and strong winds all point towards natural avalanches within the new snow. These slides could serve as the trigger for the much deeper avalanches. Even if you don’t suspect a persistent slab issue exists, avoid all steep open slopes as this storm plays out.
forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Storm Slab
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Storm Slab avalanches are the release of a cohesive layer (a slab) of new snow that breaks within new snow or on the old snow surface. Storm-slabs typically last between a few hours and few days (following snowfall). Storm-slabs that form over a persistent weak layer (surface hoar, depth hoar, or near-surface facets) may be termed Persistent Slabs or may develop into Persistent Slabs.

145.author: Matt Primomo
145.bottom_line: Large and surprising natural and human triggered avalanches have occurred in the zone, running on a variety of weak layers. New snow and strong wind will continue dangerous conditions at upper elevations on Friday.  Consider dialing back your terrain significantly, avoiding entire features where wind has created cohesive slabs, and stay alert to signs of instability such as shooting cracks and whumphs.
145.hazard_discussion:
Two large, ski triggered avalanches were reported late in the day on Tuesday, one of which was a close call, and on Wednesday suspected natural avalanches were observed in Portley Bowl. With recent observations of buried surface hoar from January 30th, we suspect this layer as the culprit. Observers reported about 1.5' of snow above the Jan 30th interface in the Washington Pass area. This layer presents as surface hoar or a thin sun crust on solar aspects. Professionals found this layer as small surface hoar at 5,700ft in Cutthroat on a southeast aspect, with clean planer results with tilt tests. Another potential failure layer is small facets within, or above a crust from January 13th. This prominent crust can be found about 2ft below the surface. 

Further east in the zone, the weakened crust from January 13th has been a concern, even below treeline. Observers in the Twisp drainage reported collapsing at 4,800ft on a northeast aspect on Monday, and snowpack tests show potential for avalanches to propagate. Also on Monday, a large avalanche was heard in the Lost River drainage following a period of warming and light to moderate precipitation. To sum it up, we have higher uncertainty with the shallower and weaker snowpack in the eastern part of the zone. If you travel to areas such as the Chelan-Sawtooth Mountains, Twisp River, and Chewuch drainages, take time to dig in the snow and look for older weak layers. Consider traveling in lower angle terrain and smaller terrain features.  You'll need to evaluate the upper snowpack carefully to travel safely in avalanche terrain.

During the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic, continue to follow the latest guidance from local, state, and federal health officials. Avoid unnecessary risks that could impact first responders and stress medical resources. Wear a mask when appropriate, practice social distancing, and consider recreating closer to home.

media.caption: (2/2/2021) Ski triggered avalanche in Portley Bowl. East aspect at ~7,000ft
(1/31/2021) A profile from 5,700ft, SE in Cutthroat Creek. Photo: Josh Hirshberg

(1/31/2021) The darker stripe of snow is a layer of surface hoar buried on January 30th near Washington Pass. This was found 25cm below the surface on a SE aspect at 5,700ft on January 31st. Photo: Josh Hirshberg
(1/31/2021) About a foot of recent snow produced fast and clean shears on an interface of recent snow (DF) and surface hoar.  SE, 5,750ft, Cutthroat ck. Photo: Josh Hirshberg
(1/27/2021) Storm snow over a crust has been collapsing on weaker snow below. 5,500ft in the lower Methow drainage. Photo: Drew Lovell

forecast_avalanche_problems.discussion:
Wide and surprising avalanches are possible if an avalanche runs on buried surface hoar or a crust which could be more than 2ft below the surface. With recent, large human triggered avalanches likely failing on buried surface hoar, you'll need to carefully evaluate the snowpack to travel safely in avalanche terrain. Open slopes from north to southeast aspects, and steeper than 30 degrees will be the most likely areas to trigger one of these. Surface hoar tends to survive in open, sheltered and shaded terrain, so be cognizant in unsuspecting rollovers and unsupported features even below treeline. 

Observers have noted instabilities below treeline within or below a deteriorating rain crust from January. When the snowpack is this complex, keep your terrain choices simple.

media.caption: (2/3/2021) A ski triggered avalanche was reported in Portley Bowl on 2/2. The next day an observer took the bottom photograph at 10:50AM. The majority of the rest of the slopes in the bowl had avalanched, with no ski tracks observed in or out of the slides. These may have been solar triggered, and suspected to have failed on a buried surface hoar layer from 1/30.

forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Persistent Slab
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Persistent Slab avalanches are the release of a cohesive layer of snow (a slab) in the middle to upper snowpack, when the bond to an underlying persistent weak layer breaks. Persistent layers include: surface hoar, depth hoar, near-surface facets, or faceted snow. Persistent weak layers can continue to produce avalanches for days, weeks or even months, making them especially dangerous and tricky. As additional snow and wind events build a thicker slab on top of the persistent weak layer, this avalanche problem may develop into a Deep Persistent Slab.

forecast_avalanche_problems.discussion:
New snow and strong westerly winds will continue to transport snow onto lee slopes on Friday. Wind slabs could be quite reactive as they rest over a suncrust on solar aspects, and recently buried surface hoar on shaded aspects. Feel for wind stiffened or hollow sounding snow as you climb in elevation and change aspects. Be especially careful around places like convex rollovers and unsupported slopes. Watch for shooting cracks or whumphing collapses as a clear sign of instability.  Wind slabs could also step down to other weak snow layers in the top 2ft of the snowpack.

Outside of wind affected areas, loose dry avalanches may run and entrain new snow on steep slopes. Don't let a small loose avalanche ruin your day by pushing you into terrain traps or strainers.

media.caption: Example wind slab: Long shooting cracks through wind stiffened snow are direct signs of instability.

forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Wind Slab
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Wind Slab avalanches are the release of a cohesive layer of snow (a slab) formed by the wind. Wind typically transports snow from the upwind sides of terrain features and deposits snow on the downwind side. Wind slabs are often smooth and rounded and sometimes sound hollow, and can range from soft to hard. Wind slabs that form over a persistent weak layer (surface hoar, depth hoar, or near-surface facets) may be termed Persistent Slabs or may develop into Persistent Slabs.

146.author: Matt Primomo
146.bottom_line: New snow and very strong wind will increase the chances for very dangerous hard slab avalanches at upper elevations. Slabs could be up to 4ft deep and very wide, or they could be just within the new snow. A number of close calls have occurred in the zone recently, and this combined with another storm should be enough to stay out of avalanche terrain higher in the mountains.
146.hazard_discussion:
Another storm is rolling through the Cascades with some very strong winds along with it. This one won't produce as much snow as recent storms for places like the Wenatchee Mountains, but will favor areas closer to the crest. Almost as important for avalanche conditions as the amount of new snow coming will be the winds. 

Observers reported reactive conditions on Thursday with a snowboarder taking a ride in a shallow wind slab at Mission Ridge on a Northwest aspect in the Near Treeline elevation band. An observer reported a number of large (up to D2.5) avalanches with the recent storm from February 1 or 2 near Holden Village. On Wednesday, Mission Ridge Ski Patrol reported 4 large hard slab avalanches with control work. These likely ran on the crust from 1/13, and were roughly 24"+ deep x 100ft wide in ridgetop, or near ridgetop terrain. I experienced whumpfing collapses in low angle terrain near the summit of Mt Lillian on Tuesday.  Extended column tests showed propagation was likely about 1.5' down (45 cm) above the 1/13 crust. All of these fresh reports build on previous human-triggered avalanches and widespread collapsing stretching back from last week in the eastern part of the zone including the Icicle Creek area and the Wenatchee Mountains.

In all parts of the zone, weak structure can be observed in the top 2-3 feet of the snowpack, and could result in an avalanche. These include facets resting on a crust beneath the snow that has fallen since Jan 24th, as well as more deeply buried facets sandwiched between weak crusts. At lower elevations, you'll find less new snow and a stronger recent rain crust. 

During the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic, continue to follow the latest guidance from local, state, and federal health officials. Avoid unnecessary risks that could impact first responders and stress medical resources. Wear a mask when appropriate, practice social distancing, and consider recreating closer to home.

media.caption: (2/2/2021)  A compression test shows an easy result failing top of the mid-January facet/crust combo.  NE aspect 6200' on Mt Lillian. Video by Matt Primomo
(2/2/2021) The result from an extended column test indicates propagation is possible on an East aspect at 5900 ft.  ECTP11 down 40 cm on 1/13 facet/crust combo. Photo by Matt Primomo
(2/2/2021) About 4 inches of fresh snow coats the SE side of Mt Lillian. Photo by Matt Primomo

(1/28/2021) A quick profile at the site of a large collapse with cracks running 10 feet through the snow. A thick weak layer of facets can be seen just under a crust and recent snow that fell since the 24th. Icicle drainage, NW, 6,900ft. Photo: Josh Hirshberg
(1/27/2021) Profile showing weak structure with a crust facet sandwich.

forecast_avalanche_problems.discussion:
Large persistent slabs continue to be the main concern in the East Central zone and have occurred mainly on Northwest to Southeast aspects above 5,500ft. The Salmon la Sac and other areas on the western edge of the zone boundary will do the best with this storm, and those places are likely to become very dangerous at upper elevations on Friday. The Wenatchee Mountains, Icicle, and mountains near Lake Wenatchee will continue to have these dangerous conditions as well. Snowpack tests and recent human triggered avalanches all indicate you can trigger a 2-4' slab avalanche above the prominent mid-January crust. Days of snowfall and sustained windy periods have incrementally loaded this facet/crust layer and now avalanches have become potentially unmanageable in size. When the snowpack is this complex, keep your terrain choices simple. Elevations below 4,500ft may offer significantly lower chances of triggering one of these.

Persistent slabs can propagate widely across terrain features and can result in large and deadly avalanches. Put a healthy buffer between where you travel and large open slopes steeper than 30 degrees.  Stay alert to signs of instability such as shooting cracks, and whumphing collapses.

media.caption: (2/3/2021) This natural avalanche likely occurred overnight on 02/02. Similar to other slides in the East Central, it failed on facets above the 1/13 crust in non-skier compacted terrain of Crystal Mt. It occurred on a SE aspect at 6500'. Crown depth 2'. Photo: Crystal Mountain Ski Patrol

forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Persistent Slab
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Persistent Slab avalanches are the release of a cohesive layer of snow (a slab) in the middle to upper snowpack, when the bond to an underlying persistent weak layer breaks. Persistent layers include: surface hoar, depth hoar, near-surface facets, or faceted snow. Persistent weak layers can continue to produce avalanches for days, weeks or even months, making them especially dangerous and tricky. As additional snow and wind events build a thicker slab on top of the persistent weak layer, this avalanche problem may develop into a Deep Persistent Slab.

forecast_avalanche_problems.discussion: Reactive wind slabs were observed on Thursday, and we only expect these to be larger on Friday. Extremely strong winds will continue to transport snow in exposed terrain through Friday. Feel for wind stiffened or hollow sounding snow as you climb in elevation, enter open terrain, and change aspects.  Any avalanche in the new snow could step down to deeper weaker layers and result in a very large and deadly hard slab avalanche above 5,000ft. Consider the terrain you're connected to and avoid steep, open wind loaded slopes. Stay alert to indicators of wind slab such as heavy snow drifting, shooting cracks and whumphing collapses. Small loose snow, or soft slab avalanches are possible on steep, sheltered slopes where more than 8" of new snow falls as well.

media.caption: (2/1/2021) From White Pass on Monday: Example of a small wind slab avalanche stepping down to weaker deeper layers.

forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Wind Slab
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Wind Slab avalanches are the release of a cohesive layer of snow (a slab) formed by the wind. Wind typically transports snow from the upwind sides of terrain features and deposits snow on the downwind side. Wind slabs are often smooth and rounded and sometimes sound hollow, and can range from soft to hard. Wind slabs that form over a persistent weak layer (surface hoar, depth hoar, or near-surface facets) may be termed Persistent Slabs or may develop into Persistent Slabs.

147.author: Dallas Glass
147.bottom_line: Expect the avalanche hazard to increase on Friday as windy conditions combine with new snow to form slabs at any elevation. In some areas, avalanches could break into older snowlayers and produce large and deadly slide.
147.hazard_discussion:
While this storm doesn’t look huge for the East South area, it should bring significant winds and a few inches of new snow. You could trigger avalanches in places where the winds drift the snow into deeper slabs. Blowing snow may serve as your simplest observations to identify wind loaded slopes. Drifts behind objects and changes in the depth of soft snow may also help you pick out potential trouble spots. Strong westerly winds could form slabs on exposed features at any elevation. 

We don’t know much about the snowpack structure of the East South area. However, all other zones in the Washington Cascades show persistent slabs in their forecasts. It may be a safe bet that persistent weak layers exist at least in some parts of this region too. In most areas, weak facets sit above a very thick and prominent crust (1/13). These sugary grain failed in avalanches in both adjacent zones (East Central and West South). While you can use snow profiles and snowpack tests to find and monitor these layers, don’t risk your life based on one hole in the snow. Avalanches are most likely to fail on persistent grains underneath wind loaded pockets. As a result, give all steep wind-loaded slopes a very wide berth. If you dig in the snow, help us find and track these potentially dangerous layers by submitting an observation. 

At lower elevations, a thin snowpack still exists in many locations. Shallowly buried obstacles, open creeks, and bare ground may block your path. The snowpack should increase dramatically as you ascend in elevation and get closer to the crest. 

During the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic, continue to follow the latest guidance from local, state, and federal health officials. Avoid unnecessary risks that could impact first responders and stress medical resources.  Wear a mask when appropriate, practice social distancing, and consider recreating closer to home.

media.caption: (2/1/2021) This snow profile from Miriam creek near White Pass shows the facet layer of concern.
(1/27/2021) Profile showing weak structure with a crust facet sandwich.

(1/28/2021) A skier intentionally triggered this avalanche (D2) in Icicle Creek on a north aspect at 3800ft that entrained soft snow and ran several hundred feet. The avalanche likely ran on the most recent (1/14) crust and associated weak snow (facets or surface hoar). East Central Zone
(2/1/2021) This small wind slab avalanche stepped down to the 1/23 facets above the thick prominent crust. Gunsight Bowl: N aspect, 6300',  18" crown. HS-ASc-D1.5-R2-O

(2/3/2021) This natural avalanche likely occurred overnight on 02/02. Similar to other slides it failed on facets above the 13 crust in non-skier compacted terrain of Crystal Mt. It occurred on a SE aspect at 6500'. Crown depth 2'. Photo: Crystal Mountain Ski Patrol

148.author: Robert Hahn
148.bottom_line: You can easily trigger a large and dangerous wind slab in near and above treeline terrain. Given the strong to extreme winds through Friday morning, you may find these slabs extending well below their typical start zones.  Give these slabs some respect by avoiding wind-loaded terrain steeper than 35 degrees.
148.hazard_discussion:
Mt Hood Meadows Pro Patrol reported a stabilizing upper snowpack on Thursday. The only avalanche activity involved Wet Loose on south-facing slopes due to warming and partial sunshine on the east side of Mt. Hood. You may find a thin temperature or light "mist" crust on southerly aspects extending up to 7000 ft. This thin crust may be a plane of failure for avalanche activity in some areas on Friday. 

The stout mid-January crust is considered the new "ground" with a strong snowpack structure in place below this layer. Weak and faceted snow just above the stout rain crust was responsible for a number of avalanches Thursday-Saturday, but no new evidence of avalanches on this interface suggests these facets are gaining strength. 

During the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic, continue to follow the latest guidance from local, state, and federal health officials. Avoid unnecessary risks that could impact first responders and stress medical resources.  Wear a mask when appropriate, practice social distancing, and consider recreating closer to home.

media.caption: Blowing snow, firm and textured snow, and cornice formation are all evidence that wind slabs are likely to be forming on lee slopes.
(1/16/21) Tilley Jane trail: At lower elevations, travel hazards may be lurking under the new snow.
(1/17/2021) Prior to the new snow, slopes like the one pictured here in Newton Canyon were deceptively icy. Debris from a very large (D3) wet avalanche last week can be seen in the valley bottom.

forecast_avalanche_problems.discussion:
You can trigger large and dangerous wind slabs near and above treeline. We expect 10-12" of snow to be transported by strong to extreme winds, wind-stripping or loading most slopes near and above treeline. Snow may deposit on mid-slope terrain features and where you don't expect them. Slabs are likely to be large, firm, and difficult to escape in exposed terrain. Seek wind-sheltered terrain where possible. Avoid areas of active snow transport and wind-loading. Pay attention to cracking snow surfaces and firm, punchy layering. Avoid all wind-loaded slopes steeper than 35 degrees.

Below treeline, slabs may be smaller, softer and easier to steer around if you can identify the subtle, stiffer slab or find 8" of fresh snow. In either case, keep your slope angle below 35 degrees and avoid convex rollovers.

media.caption: Blowing snow, firm and textured snow, and cornice formation are all evidence that wind slabs are likely to be forming on lee slopes.

forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Wind Slab
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Wind Slab avalanches are the release of a cohesive layer of snow (a slab) formed by the wind. Wind typically transports snow from the upwind sides of terrain features and deposits snow on the downwind side. Wind slabs are often smooth and rounded and sometimes sound hollow, and can range from soft to hard. Wind slabs that form over a persistent weak layer (surface hoar, depth hoar, or near-surface facets) may be termed Persistent Slabs or may develop into Persistent Slabs.
